page.title: 12 CUDHAM - CHURCH
page.content: {The Church of St. Peter and St.Paul} is the oldest building in the parish of Cudham. It is a pretty, knapped flint building standing on the edge of the recreation ground in the centre of the village. Mentioned in the original Domesday Book it has been altered and extended over the years and changes are still being made. The tall spire can be seen for some distance through the surrounding trees. An old tunnel once led to a monastry out on the hillside, but this has now been filled in. A large and interesting graveyard surrounds the church, some of the tombstones dating back many hundreds of years. Sheep are used to keep the grass short during the summer. Two ancient yew trees stand on the south side of the church. (See Page 15)
